It's hard to imagine that almost every current K-12 student was born after the 9/11 tragedy. Because they don't actually remember it, it's important to teach them about the courage that first responders, and average citizens, showed on that fateful day.

Thanks to the C.O. Harrison Elementary School administrators, staff and students for their beautiful, red-white-and-blue observance of Patriot Day today, and to Delhi Township Fire Chief Douglas Campbell for stopping by to share some thoughts on the lessons of 9/11.

"Americans put aside their differences by coming together and showing the power of patriotism by reaching deep into their souls and finding the strength to love and help their neighbor no matter the color of their skin, their religious background or how much money they had. It simply didn't matter," Chief Campbell told the COH students.

The 2020 Save Local Waters Rain Barrel Auction is Happening Soon!

The Rain Barrel Art Project was created to promote the use of rain barrels throughout the Ohio River Valley area through a creative and educational medium. The Rain Barrel Art Project desires to educate people on environmental issues like stormwater runoff, watersheds, and water conservation.

This year, Ms. Kopf‚Äôs Painting and Mixed Media students created 3 Rain Barrels for this year's event. The effects of COVID-19 impacted the original display and auction dates but the event will still go on with the following revised dates!
The rain barrels are located in the Lale'enok Resource Centre, located across from the Savannah area headed towards the painted dogs at the Cincinnati Zoo.

The Rain Barrel auction will go live on July 18th at 6pm and will end on July 28th at 6pm. The auction will be hosted on eBay's auction platform.

Take a look at the rain barrels here, or at the Zoo, before the auction starts. The official auctions listing can be found here on July 18th. https://www.savelocalwaters.org/auction.html

Bus drivers are an essential part of our school district. They play a vital role in keeping our students -- and our community -- safe. For more information on this position, please email or call Transportation Supervisor Tracy Marcum at sprague_t@ohlsd.org, 513-574-2161.

The Oak Hills Local School District is sending warm thoughts, hearty congratulations and many thanks today to OHHS arts educator Jamie Schorsch who was this year's Hamilton County Education Foundation's Educator of the Year for Oak Hills Local Schools. The ceremony was planned for today but cancelled because of the COVID-19 pandemic and Ohio's stay at home order.

In our book, Ms. Schorsch is truly a winner every day. She is a gifted visual arts instructor and coordinator of the Art & Design Department, and the endless champion and encourager of her students. The work that flows out of her classroom is nothing short of breathtaking. The joy that flows from her students is beautiful to see.

This year, a record 61 OHHS art students earned recognition in the national Scholastic Art Awards program, and senior Cailee Plunkett was a finalist in the prestigious Overture Awards competition. It is a testimony to Oak Hills' amazing K-12 art program and to our incredible art teachers, including Ms. Schorsch. Thanks for representing OHLSD so well.

Instead of taking our coronavirus/quarantine frustration out on the people around us, wouldn't it be great if we could actually take it out on THE CORONAVIRUS? That's the clever thinking behind the Quarantine Fun Day going on with J.F. Dulles fourth graders today.

Students in Mrs. Brown's, Mrs. Abel's and Mrs. Duwel's classes were challenged to draw a picture of the nasty virus and then destroy it in any creative way they like. Batting, kicking, stomping, crushing -- take that, COVID-19!

Once their fury subsides, students are invited to write notes of support to workers who are directly serving their families, like postal carriers, delivery people and sanitation workers. Finally, they're going to write to patients in nursing homes or hospitals.

So. . . if we see a quick downturn in the number of cases of COVID-19, we'll know whom to thank!

A volunteer at the University of Cincinnati Medical Center and for Special Olympics and other causes, Caroline is guided by her desire to help people through a career in medicine. Her stellar achievements are enhanced by her incredible work ethic, personal warmth and humility.

All of us in Oak Hills Local Schools are proud of Caroline's accomplishments and delighted at her recognition. She represents the best of the Highlander tradition.

These workshops, run by the OHHS robotics team, are proving wildly popular. The engineering workshop takes place Monday, Feb. 3, at OHHS and includes grades 3-12. Students can sign up for a morning session (8 a.m.-11 a.m.), an afternoon session (12 p.m.-3 p.m.) or both sessions. A pizza lunch is included for students enrolling in both sessions.
Cost is $50 per session. Register here:http://bit.ly/2RWr4Bf

Congratulations to the Oak Hills Athletic Department, which has just been awarded a $25,000 grant through the Heber Holbrook Hutchinson Endowment Fund. The generous grant will provide athletic equipment for 11 sports and specialized equipment for students with special needs.

Many thanks to the Hutchinson Endowment Fund and to the Johnson Charitable Gift Fund Board, which awarded the grant.

The Hutchinson family business, Hutch Sporting Goods, provided sporting equipment to hundreds of young athletes throughout its existence in the mid-1900s.

Oak Hills Local Schools sends congratulations and thanks to our friend and neighbor, St. Dominic School, for hosting a beautiful naturalization ceremony today for 70 new Americans from 32 countries. U.S. Magistrate Judge Karen L. Litkovitz ended the event by saying, "I welcome you into the American family."
Thanks, St. Dominic staff and PTO, for including OHLSD in this special day!
